metadata.title: Guide to Analyzing and Reporting Participant Groups in Pol.is Conversations
metadata.purpose: Generate consistent, evidence-based reports comparing participant groups and describing their distinctive voting behaviors and patterns

criticalInstructions.instruction: Generate a JSON response that conforms to the provided schema. DO NOT INCLUDE ANY OTHER TEXT.
DO NOT return ```json at the beginning of the response. This is not markdown. Do not end the response with ```, your response MUST begin with { and end with }
Focus on PARTICIPANT GROUP VOTING BEHAVIORS, not comment topic analysis. These are groups of people with similar voting patterns, not groups of similar comments.

term.name: participant_group
term.description: A cluster of participants who exhibit similar voting patterns across the conversation, identified through UMAP dimensionality reduction of participant voting vectors

term.name: distinctive_voting_pattern
term.description: Voting behavior that significantly differentiates one participant group from others

term.name: group_consensus
term.description: Comments where a participant group shows strong internal agreement

term.name: one_vs_all_analysis
term.description: Analytical approach comparing each participant group's voting patterns against the combined patterns of all other groups

criticalInstructions.instruction: Focus on PARTICIPANT BEHAVIOR PATTERNS, not comment content themes. Describe how different groups of people approached voting in the conversation.
Explain the UMAP clustering approach and how it identified groups based on voting similarity.
Avoid confusing participant groups with comment topic clusters - these are fundamentally different analytical approaches.

paragraph.format:
UMAP clustering analysis of participant voting patterns identified [number_of_groups] distinct behavioral groups within the conversation. These groups were formed based on similarity in voting behaviors across all comments, revealing [number_of_groups] different approaches to engaging with the conversation topics.
The participant groups varied significantly in size, with Group [X] comprising approximately [percentage]% of participants, while Group [Y] represented [percentage]% of the total. These size differences reflect the diversity of behavioral approaches within the conversation.
The most significant behavioral distinctions emerged in how groups approached [key_voting_pattern_difference], with some groups showing [description_of_distinctive_behavior] while others demonstrated [contrasting_behavior]. This pattern of differential engagement highlighted fundamental differences in how participants [specific_behavioral_characteristic].

paragraphInstructions.instruction: Provide a comprehensive overview that: - Introduces the participant clustering methodology - Describes all identified participant groups - Highlights major behavioral distinctions between groups - Focuses on voting patterns rather than comment content - Provides group size information and distribution - Sets context for detailed group analysis

criticalInstructions.instruction: For each participant group, explain HOW they voted differently from other groups, not WHAT topics they voted on. Focus on behavioral patterns and voting consistency.
Use one-vs-all analysis to highlight what makes each group unique compared to all other participants combined.
Provide specific examples of distinctive voting behaviors with exact percentages and comment citations.

paragraph.format:
Group [A], comprising [participant_count] participants ([percentage]% of total), demonstrated a distinctive pattern of [behavioral_characteristic]. In one-vs-all analysis, this group showed significantly [higher/lower] agreement rates on statements related to [topic_area], with [specific_percentage]% agreement compared to [other_percentage]% among all other participants.
This behavioral pattern was most evident in their response to [specific_comment_type], where Group [A] consistently [agreed/disagreed] at rates [percentage_difference]% different from the remaining participant population. Their voting behavior suggested a [characterization_of_approach] approach to the conversation topics.
Group [B]'s [participant_count] participants ([percentage]% of total) exhibited contrasting behavioral patterns, characterized by [different_behavioral_characteristic]. Their distinctive feature was [specific_voting_pattern], particularly evident in their responses to [comment_category] where they showed [percentage]% agreement compared to [other_percentage]% among other groups combined.
[Continue for additional groups...]

paragraphInstructions.instruction: For each participant group, provide: - Clear characterization of distinctive voting behaviors - Specific examples with percentages and comment citations - One-vs-all comparative analysis highlighting uniqueness - Group size and composition information - Analysis of behavioral consistency within the group - Interpretation of what the voting patterns suggest about group approach

case.description: Participant group that shows mixed voting patterns across different topic areas
Participant group with significantly higher voting participation rates
Participant group that tends to vote similarly to overall population averages

validationRules.rule: All behavioral characterizations must be based on quantitative voting pattern analysis
Each behavioral claim requires at least two supporting comment citations
Citations must reference specific comments that demonstrate the behavioral pattern
Group references must use actual group identifiers from clustering data
Percentages must be reported for all comparative claims
One-vs-all analysis must be included for each group
